Description: A mild viral infection affecting the upper respiratory tract.
A viral respiratory infection causing fever and fatigue.
A contagious viral infection affecting the respiratory system.
Lung infection causing breathing difficulty and chest discomfort.
Inflammation of bronchial tubes causing mucus buildup and cough.
Chronic airway inflammation causing wheezing and breathlessness.
Sinus cavity inflammation leading to facial pressure and headache.
Voice box inflammation causing hoarseness and throat irritation.
Bacterial infection of lungs that spreads through air.
Bacterial infection causing uncontrollable coughs.
Inflammation of the lung lining causing sharp chest pain.
Stomach lining inflammation often from infection or stress.
Intestinal infection causing diarrhea and cramps.
Illness caused by contaminated food or water.
Digestive disorder causing abdominal discomfort.
Stomach lining erosion from acid.
Inflammation of the appendix causing severe lower-right pain.
Liver inflammation from viral infection or toxins.
Hardened bile deposits causing gallbladder pain.
Pancreas inflammation often due to alcohol or gallstones.
Difficulty in passing stool regularly.
Backflow of acid from stomach into esophagus.
Precautions: Eat small meals;Avoid spicy foods;Don’t lie after eating

Description: Blockage of coronary artery causing tissue death.
Persistently high blood pressure causing heart strain.
Irregular heartbeat leading to fainting or tiredness.
Hardening of arteries causing reduced blood flow.
Loss of brain blood flow causing paralysis.
Low hemoglobin or red blood cell levels.
Reduced blood flow to the heart causing chest pain. It often precedes heart attack if untreated.
A disease of the heart muscle that makes it harder to pump blood. It may lead to heart failure.
Inflammation of the pericardial sac surrounding the heart. Causes sharp chest pain that worsens when lying down.
Blood clot formation in deep veins, usually legs. It can travel to lungs causing embolism.
Enlarged, twisted veins caused by weak valves. They commonly appear in legs and worsen after standing long.
Infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers or valves. It’s often bacterial and requires antibiotics.
Narrowing of arteries reduces blood supply to limbs. It can cause pain while walking.
A bulging weak spot in the aorta that can rupture. Immediate surgical attention is required if detected.
A blood clot blocking arteries in the lungs. It’s a life-threatening emergency requiring prompt care.
The heart fails to pump blood efficiently, leading to fluid buildup. It can result from long-term hypertension or heart disease.
Severe throbbing headache due to nerve inflammation.
Brain disorder with recurrent seizures.
Sensation of spinning or imbalance.
Brain disorder causing tremors and stiffness.
Progressive brain disease causing memory decline.
Autoimmune disease damaging nerve coverings.
Inflammation of membranes surrounding brain and spine.
Abnormal growth of brain cells causing pressure and neurological deficits. Symptoms depend on tumor location.
Inflammation of the brain due to viral infection. It requires urgent medical treatment to prevent damage.
Sudden paralysis of facial muscles due to nerve inflammation. Usually resolves within weeks with treatment.
An autoimmune condition attacking peripheral nerves. It may progress rapidly and affect breathing.
Compression of the median nerve in the wrist causing pain and numbness. Common in repetitive hand movements.
Damage to peripheral nerves causing pain or loss of sensation. Diabetes and toxins are common causes.
A degenerative nerve disorder leading to muscle paralysis. Gradual progression affects speaking and breathing.
A group of disorders affecting movement and posture from birth injury. It’s non-progressive but lifelong.
A neurological sleep disorder causing sudden sleep attacks. It affects concentration and safety.
A group of conditions causing decline in cognitive ability. Alzheimer’s is the most common cause.
Fungal growth on skin or scalp causing irritation.
Skin condition causing dryness and redness.
Autoimmune condition causing dry
Skin reaction to irritants or allergens.
Blocked pores leading to bacterial infection.
Skin injury from UV radiation.
High blood sugar due to insulin deficiency.
Underactive thyroid causing low metabolism.
Overactive thyroid increasing metabolism.
Hormonal disorder in women causing infertility.
Excessive body fat increasing health risks.
A rare endocrine disorder where adrenal glands don’t produce enough hormones. It causes weakness, dehydration, and salt craving.
Precautions: Corticosteroid therapy;Adequate salt intake;Regular medical follow-up

Description: Excess cortisol in the body due to tumor or medication. It leads to central obesity and fragile skin.
Excess growth hormone secretion usually from pituitary tumor. It causes abnormal bone and tissue growth.
A rare adrenal gland tumor that produces excess adrenaline. It can trigger dangerous spikes in blood pressure.
A condition where kidneys fail to conserve water due to hormone imbalance. It causes frequent urination and thirst.
A cluster of metabolic abnormalities increasing heart disease risk. Linked with poor diet and inactivity.
Precautions: Exercise;Balanced diet;Monitor blood sugar and BP

Description: Overactive parathyroid glands increase calcium levels in blood. It causes kidney stones and bone weakness.
Low parathyroid hormone levels cause calcium deficiency. It results in muscle spasms and irritability.
Thyroid gland enlargement often due to iodine deficiency. Large goiters may cause breathing difficulty.
Low blood sugar levels usually due to medication overdose. Immediate glucose intake is required to prevent fainting.
Urinary tract infection due to bacteria.
Solid crystals in kidneys causing pain.
Loss of kidney function requiring dialysis.
Pain during menstruation due to uterine contractions.
Growth of uterine tissue outside uterus.
Prostate gland inflammation causing pain.
Fluid-filled sacs that develop on ovaries. Large cysts can cause discomfort or menstrual changes.
Benign tumors in uterus causing heavy periods. They shrink after menopause or with treatment.
Bacterial infection of female reproductive organs. It may cause infertility if untreated.
Inability to conceive after a year of regular intercourse. Can result from male or female reproductive problems.
Inability to maintain erection due to physical or psychological causes. Often linked with diabetes or heart disease.
A malignant tumor of the prostate gland in older men. Early stages are often symptomless.
A malignancy of the ovaries that spreads silently. It’s detected late due to vague early symptoms.
Cancer of uterine lining common after menopause. It often presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding.
Caused by persistent HPV infection. It is preventable through vaccination and screening.
A cancer in the testicles that mainly affects young men. Early detection ensures high cure rates.
Persistent sadness affecting mental health.
Excessive worry and uneasiness about events.
Alternating episodes of mania and depression.
Mental disorder causing hallucinations and delusions.
Sudden intense anxiety with physical reactions.
Inability to fall or stay asleep.
Developmental disorder affecting communication.
Neurodevelopmental disorder causing hyperactivity.
Joint inflammation causing pain and swelling.
Weakening of bones increasing fracture risk.
Degeneration of neck vertebrae
Nerve compression causing radiating leg pain.
Uric acid buildup in joints causing pain.
A chronic pain syndrome affecting muscles and soft tissues. Often associated with sleep problems and anxiety.
Inflammation of a tendon from repetitive strain. Common in shoulder, elbow, and wrist.
Inflammation of fluid-filled sacs (bursae) around joints. Common in knees and elbows due to overuse.
Nerve compression in the wrist causing pain and tingling. Common among computer users and factory workers.
A curvature of the spine developing during growth. Severe cases may cause lung compression.
A slipped disc compresses spinal nerves causing pain and numbness. Common in the lumbar region.
Overuse of forearm muscles causes tendon inflammation. Pain worsens with gripping or lifting.
Inflammation of shoulder capsule limits motion. Often follows injury or diabetes.
Softening of bones due to Vitamin D deficiency in children. Leads to bowed legs and slow growth.
Degenerative joint disease from cartilage wear. Common in knees, hips, and spine of older adults.
Viral infection causing itchy blisters.
Viral infection with rash and fever.
Viral infection of salivary glands.
Bacterial infection affecting throat.
Bacterial infection causing muscle contractions.
Viral infection affecting nerves
Overheating due to high temperature
Dangerous drop in body temperature
Discomfort during travel
Loss of body fluids due to heat or illness
Inhalation of carbon monoxide gas reduces oxygen in blood. It leads to confusion, fainting, or death.
Precautions: Move to fresh air;Seek emergency care;Install detectors

Description: Prolonged heat exposure causes dehydration and salt loss. Can progress to heat stroke if untreated.
Freezing of skin and tissues due to extreme cold exposure. Commonly affects fingers, toes, ears, and nose.
Occurs at high altitudes due to low oxygen. It causes dizziness and shortness of breath.
Caused by excessive exposure to ionizing radiation. Damages cells and organs quickly.
Tissue injury due to corrosive chemical contact. Severity depends on exposure time and substance.
Triggered by long-term exposure to workplace irritants. Early diagnosis prevents chronic damage.
Caused by repeated exposure to loud noise damaging ear cells. It develops gradually and is irreversible.
Precautions: Use ear protection;Limit exposure;Regular hearing test

Description: An autoimmune disorder causing painful joint inflammation. Over time, it can lead to joint deformity if untreated.
An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks tissues and organs. It affects joints, kidneys, and skin.
Precautions: Avoid sun exposure;Take prescribed meds;Regular monitoring

Description: A gluten intolerance causing damage to the small intestine. Symptoms improve with a gluten-free diet.
Precautions: Avoid gluten;Consult dietitian;Eat naturally gluten-free foods

Description: An autoimmune condition causing hypothyroidism. The immune system gradually destroys the thyroid gland.
An autoimmune disorder causing overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism). It increases metabolism and heart rate.
An inflammatory disease forming tiny clumps of cells in lungs and lymph nodes. It can affect multiple organs.
A form of arthritis that mainly affects the spine and pelvis joints. It causes chronic back pain and stiffness.
A neuromuscular disorder causing weakness in voluntary muscles. Symptoms worsen with activity and improve with rest.
An autoimmune disease causing hardening and tightening of skin and tissues. It can affect internal organs too.
An autoimmune disease combining psoriasis and arthritis. It causes joint inflammation and skin lesions.
A viral liver infection transmitted through blood or fluids. It can lead to chronic liver disease.
A viral liver infection spread through contaminated needles. Chronic infection can cause cirrhosis or cancer.
Accumulation of fat in liver cells causing mild inflammation. It’s common in obesity or alcohol overuse.
Chronic liver scarring from alcohol or hepatitis damage. It impairs detoxification and nutrient metabolism.
Swollen veins in the rectum or anus causing pain and itching. Straining or constipation worsens symptoms.
A peptic ulcer caused by stomach acid erosion. It causes sharp pain and indigestion.
Inflammation of the colon lining leading to cramps and urgency. It may be ulcerative or infectious.
A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting any digestive part. It alternates between flare-ups and remission.
Inability to digest lactose from milk due to enzyme deficiency. Causes discomfort after dairy consumption.
Precautions: Avoid dairy;Use lactose-free products;Take lactase supplements

Description: A small tear in the anal lining due to hard stool. It causes sharp pain during bowel movements.
A bacterial infection from contaminated food or water. It causes prolonged fever and weakness.
A mosquito-borne viral disease causing low platelets and bleeding. Severe cases lead to shock.
A viral illness spread by mosquitoes causing severe joint pain. Recovery may take several weeks.
A mosquito-borne infection caused by *Plasmodium* parasites. It leads to cyclic fever and chills.
A bacterial disease transmitted through water contaminated with animal urine. It can affect kidneys and liver.
A viral infection that weakens the immune system. It increases susceptibility to opportunistic infections.
A fatal viral disease transmitted by bites of infected animals. It affects the brain and nerves.
A bacterial infection releasing toxins that cause muscle rigidity. It can be prevented by vaccination.
A rare bacterial disease spread by fleas on rodents. Untreated plague can be fatal.
A mosquito-borne viral infection that can cause birth defects. Pregnant women are at special risk.
A severe viral hemorrhagic fever with high fatality. Spread occurs through body fluids.
A now-eradicated viral disease causing pustular rash and fever. It was eliminated by vaccination worldwide.
A virus from rodent droppings causing lung disease. It can progress rapidly to respiratory failure.
A mosquito-transmitted viral infection affecting liver and kidneys. Vaccination offers lifelong protection.
Low vitamin D impairs calcium absorption and bone health. It can cause rickets in children or osteomalacia in adults.
Low iron intake or blood loss reduces hemoglobin levels. It causes tiredness and poor concentration.
Insufficient calcium weakens bones and affects nerves. Long-term deficiency may lead to osteoporosis.
Inadequate protein intake leads to muscle wasting and poor immunity. Common in malnutrition or chronic illness.
Severe protein deficiency in children causing edema and stunted growth. Common in famine-hit areas.
Caloric deficiency causing severe wasting and weakness. It occurs in extreme malnutrition.
Vitamin C deficiency affecting collagen synthesis. Causes gum bleeding and poor wound healing.
Vitamin D deficiency in children causing soft, deformed bones. Early treatment prevents permanent changes.
Excess body fat accumulation leading to metabolic disorders. It increases risk of diabetes and heart disease.
Elevated blood cholesterol increasing risk of heart attack. Often linked with poor diet and genetics.
A malignant tumor in breast tissue, often detected as a lump or skin dimpling. Early detection greatly improves outcomes.
A cancer starting in lung tissue often linked with smoking or pollutants. Persistent cough and fatigue are early signs.
Cancer of the large intestine that grows silently for years. Detected through colonoscopy and biopsy.
A deadly cancer with few early symptoms, often discovered late. It affects digestion and liver function.
Precautions: Avoid smoking;Healthy diet;Early testing if family history

Description: A cancer that develops from chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis. Causes yellowing of skin and upper-abdominal pain.
A cancer of blood-forming tissues, disrupting white blood cell function. Leads to frequent infections and bleeding.
Cancer of lymphatic system causing immune dysfunction. Symptoms include painless lymph node swelling and fever.
Abnormal skin cell growth due to UV exposure. Early recognition of changing moles is crucial.
Common in older men, this cancer grows slowly in the prostate gland. Regular PSA screening detects early cases.
A malignancy of the ovaries that spreads silently. Early stages have vague symptoms like bloating and discomfort.
A chromosomal disorder (Trisomy 21) causing intellectual disability and distinctive features. Early therapy improves development.
A genetic disorder affecting mucus glands and lungs. Leads to chronic lung infections and poor digestion.
Inherited blood disorder causing abnormally shaped red blood cells. Results in pain crises and anemia.
Genetic clotting disorder causing prolonged bleeding. Mostly affects males due to X-linked mutation.
A hereditary anemia causing reduced hemoglobin production. Requires lifelong blood transfusion in severe forms.
A genetic disorder in females missing one X chromosome. Causes growth delay and infertility.
Genetic condition in males with extra X chromosome. Leads to low testosterone and learning issues.
A connective tissue disorder affecting heart and eyes. People are tall and at risk of aortic rupture.
Inherited condition with lack of melanin pigment. Affects skin protection and vision.
A genetic cause of intellectual disability, more common in males. It may present with hyperactivity and speech delay.
Clouding of the eye lens causing gradual vision loss. Surgery restores normal sight.
Precautions: Wear sunglasses;Regular eye exams;Surgery if needed

Description: Increased eye pressure damages optic nerve. Leads to permanent vision loss if untreated.
Precautions: Eye drops;Regular eye check;Surgery in severe cases

Description: Also called pink eye, it’s inflammation of the eye membrane. Caused by infection or allergy.
Precautions: Avoid touching eyes;Use prescribed drops;Maintain hygiene

Description: Aging-related damage to retina’s center (macula). It causes progressive vision loss in older adults.
Separation of retina from its layer leading to blindness. Requires emergency surgery.
Precautions: Seek immediate care;Avoid heavy activity;Eye protection

Description: Middle ear infection common in children. Causes pain and fluid buildup behind the eardrum.
Precautions: Pain relief;Keep ears dry;Antibiotics if bacterial

Description: Infection of outer ear canal caused by moisture (swimmer’s ear). It leads to itching and pain.
Precautions: Avoid water;Use ear drops;Keep ear clean

Description: A persistent ringing or buzzing in the ears without external sound. Often caused by loud noise exposure.
Inner ear disorder causing vertigo and hearing loss. Attacks may last hours and cause imbalance.
Inherited condition affecting color perception. Commonly red-green color blindness in men.
Precautions: Color aids;Avoid confusion in labeling;Genetic counseling

Description: An autoimmune disease attacking joint linings. It causes pain, deformity, and disability if untreated.
An autoimmune disease damaging multiple organs and skin. Triggers include stress and sunlight.
An autoimmune disorder affecting tear and saliva glands. Causes dryness and discomfort in mouth and eyes.
Combination of psoriasis and arthritis symptoms. It affects both skin and joints.
Inflammation of blood vessels reducing blood flow. It can damage organs if untreated.
The immune system attacks liver cells causing inflammation. Early treatment prevents cirrhosis.
A rare condition where the immune system attacks nerves. It can cause paralysis and respiratory failure.
Autoimmune reaction to gluten damaging intestines. Leads to nutrient deficiency and stomach discomfort.
The immune system attacks thyroid tissue leading to hypothyroidism. Common in middle-aged women.
A type of arthritis that fuses spinal bones. Causes pain and reduced flexibility in young adults.
Reduced hemoglobin causes decreased oxygen delivery. Often due to iron deficiency or chronic disease.
A cancer of blood and bone marrow causing overproduction of white cells. Leads to weakness and recurrent infections.
Inherited anemia due to defective hemoglobin. Requires periodic blood transfusions.
Red cells assume a sickle shape blocking blood flow. Causes pain crises and organ damage.
Inherited bleeding disorder due to clotting factor deficiency. Even small cuts may cause long bleeding.
Abnormal increase in red blood cells thickens blood. Raises risk of stroke or clots.
Low platelet count leading to easy bleeding. Often caused by infection or drugs.
Cancer of lymph system causing immune dysfunction. Detected by biopsy or imaging.
A cancer of plasma cells in bone marrow. Leads to brittle bones and kidney issues.
Excess iron storage in body tissues damages liver and heart. Usually genetic (hemochromatosis).
A contagious viral infection affecting the respiratory system. Symptoms resemble cold but with higher fever and body pain.
A mild viral infection of the upper airways. It’s self-limiting but spreads easily through droplets.
A contagious coronavirus infection causing respiratory distress. Severe cases affect lungs and oxygen levels.
A viral infection common in infants causing bronchiolitis. It spreads through droplets and close contact.
A liver infection caused by contaminated food or water. It’s preventable with vaccination.
A liver infection spread via blood and body fluids. Chronic cases may lead to liver failure or cancer.
A blood-borne liver disease that can cause chronic infection. Early detection reduces liver damage risk.
A waterborne viral infection affecting the liver. Common in developing countries with poor sanitation.
A mosquito-borne viral infection causing mild illness in adults. Dangerous during pregnancy due to birth defects.
A mosquito-borne viral fever causing severe joint pain. Symptoms resemble dengue but with less bleeding.
A mosquito-borne viral illness causing low platelets and bleeding risk. Severe dengue can be life-threatening.
A viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. It affects the liver and kidneys and is preventable by vaccination.
A severe hemorrhagic fever with high fatality. It spreads through direct contact with body fluids.
A fatal viral infection transmitted through animal bites. It affects the brain and nervous system.
A viral infection causing painful blisters around mouth or genitals. It remains dormant and can reactivate.
Precautions: Antiviral therapy;Avoid skin contact during outbreak

Description: A viral infection causing itchy rashes and blisters. Mostly mild but contagious until all blisters dry.
A contagious viral disease with rash and respiratory symptoms. It can lead to pneumonia or brain inflammation.
A viral infection of salivary glands causing jaw swelling and pain. Preventable by MMR vaccine.
A mild viral infection with pink rash, dangerous in pregnancy. Preventable through MMR vaccination.
A viral disease affecting nerves and causing paralysis. Eradicated in many regions through immunization.
A bacterial infection of the lungs caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It spreads through air droplets.
A bacterial disease from contaminated food or water. Causes prolonged fever and weakness.
A chronic bacterial infection affecting skin and nerves. Curable with multidrug therapy if detected early.
A bacterial throat infection producing toxins. It may block airways if untreated.
A bacterial infection releasing toxins causing muscle rigidity. Vaccination prevents it effectively.
Also known as whooping cough, a respiratory bacterial disease. Dangerous in infants and unvaccinated people.
A bacterial infection from contaminated water causing severe dehydration. Without treatment, it’s fatal.
A rare bacterial infection spread by fleas on rodents. It can lead to septicemia or pneumonia.
A bacterial illness caused by Streptococcus infection. It commonly affects children after strep throat.
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus causes skin and wound infections. It’s resistant to many antibiotics.
A bacterial infection spread by tick bites. It can affect joints and nervous system if untreated.
A bacterial infection from water contaminated by animal urine. It may affect kidneys and liver.
A bacterial infection of membranes covering brain and spine. Rapid treatment is crucial to prevent death.
A skin infection caused by dermatophyte fungi. Commonly affects groin, feet, or scalp.
Yeast infection caused by Candida, affecting mouth or genitals. Common in diabetes or antibiotic use.
A fungal skin infection forming circular rashes. Highly contagious through contact or towels.
Fungal infection between toes due to moisture. Common in athletes or tight shoes.
Fungal infection under nails causing thickening and breakage. Slow to heal but treatable.
Fungal infection of the mouth caused by Candida. Common in immunocompromised individuals.
Fungal infection from soil contaminated with bird droppings. Affects lungs and can spread to organs.
Lung infection caused by inhaling Aspergillus spores. Dangerous in people with weak immunity.
A mosquito-borne parasitic infection causing cyclic fever. It can damage liver and red blood cells.
Parasitic intestinal infection by Entamoeba histolytica. Causes bloody diarrhea and cramps.
An intestinal infection caused by Giardia parasite. Spread by contaminated water or food.
Parasitic infection often spread by cats or undercooked meat. Dangerous in pregnancy.
A waterborne parasitic disease caused by flukes. Common in tropical regions with stagnant water.
Intestinal parasite from contaminated meat. Causes malnutrition and discomfort.
Common in children, causes anal itching due to worm eggs. Easily spreads through contaminated hands.
Parasitic infection spread by sandfly bites. It affects skin, spleen, and liver.
Sinus inflammation causing pressure and headache. Often follows cold or allergy.
Inflammation of tonsils caused by viral or bacterial infection. Common in school-age children.
Inflammation of the throat usually viral. Causes irritation and pain when swallowing.
Middle ear infection due to bacteria or virus. Common in infants after a cold.
Voice box inflammation causing hoarseness and pain. Often due to overuse or viral infection.
Inflammation of nasal mucosa due to allergy or infection. Common in seasonal allergies.
A genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system. Mucus builds up causing frequent infections.
Inherited disorder causing red blood cells to become crescent-shaped. Leads to pain crises and anemia.
Inherited blood disorder reducing hemoglobin. Requires regular transfusions for severe cases.
A genetic clotting disorder causing prolonged bleeding. Mostly affects males due to X-linked inheritance.
A connective tissue disorder affecting heart, eyes, and skeleton. Increases risk of aortic rupture.
An inherited neurodegenerative disease that affects movement and cognition. Symptoms worsen gradually over years.
A group of inherited diseases causing progressive muscle degeneration. Often starts in childhood.
A metabolic genetic disorder where the body can’t process phenylalanine. Untreated, it leads to brain damage.
Inherited condition lacking melanin pigment. Increases risk of sunburn and vision problems.
A rare inherited disorder destroying nerve cells in the brain. It’s fatal in early childhood.
Abnormal protein deposits (amyloid) build up in organs. It affects the heart, kidneys, and nerves.
Adrenal glands fail to produce hormones like cortisol. Causes dehydration and muscle weakness.
Excess cortisol from tumor or medication. Leads to obesity and fragile skin.
A rare inherited liver disease causing copper buildup. It affects brain and liver function.
A genetic enzyme deficiency causing fat accumulation in organs. Causes anemia and bone pain.
Inherited condition causing excessive iron absorption. Iron deposits damage organs over time.
An autoimmune disorder causing muscle weakness. Worsens with activity and improves with rest.
A connective tissue disease causing hardening of skin and organs. It reduces flexibility and blood flow.
A connective tissue disorder making skin stretchy and fragile. Increases risk of dislocation and bleeding.
Inflammatory disease forming small clumps in lungs and lymph nodes. It can affect multiple organs.
Cancer of blood-forming tissues leading to abnormal white cells. Causes weakness and recurrent infections.
Cancer of lymphatic system impairing immunity. Detected by biopsy or scan.
A cancer of plasma cells affecting bones and kidneys. Causes brittle bones and anemia.
A serious skin cancer developing from moles. Early detection ensures high survival rate.
Most common skin cancer caused by UV exposure. Rarely spreads but causes local damage.
A skin cancer growing in outer layers due to UV or radiation. Can spread to lymph nodes if ignored.
Abnormal cell growth inside the brain or spinal cord. May be benign or malignant.
A tumor in the thyroid gland often detected as a neck lump. Early stages are curable.
Malignant tumor in bladder lining causing urinary symptoms. Often linked to smoking or chemicals.
Cancer originating in bone tissue causing persistent pain. Requires chemotherapy and surgery.
Excess body fat increases risk of diabetes and heart disease. Caused by overeating and inactivity.
Metabolic disorder where the body resists insulin. Leads to nerve and kidney damage over time.
Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells. Usually diagnosed in children or young adults.
Excess cholesterol builds up in arteries increasing heart disease risk. It’s often symptomless until severe.
High blood pressure strains heart and vessels. Untreated cases lead to stroke or heart attack.
Uric acid buildup causes crystal formation in joints. Triggers include alcohol and red meat.
Underactive thyroid slows metabolism and energy production. Common in middle-aged women.
Overactive thyroid increases metabolism and causes tremors. Usually due to Graves’ disease.
Hormonal disorder in women causing irregular cycles and infertility. Linked to insulin resistance.
Cluster of metabolic problems increasing heart disease risk. Caused by sedentary lifestyle.
Breathing repeatedly stops during sleep causing poor oxygenation. Linked to obesity and airway blockage.
Accumulation of fat in liver cells leading to inflammation. Common in obesity and diabetes.
Stomach acid flows back into the esophagus causing burning. Worsened by fatty food or late meals.
Precautions: Eat small meals;Avoid spicy foods;Don’t lie after eating

Description: Digestive disorder due to stress and diet imbalance. Causes discomfort and irregular bowel movement.
A neurological condition causing severe headaches. Often triggered by light, stress, or sleep deprivation.
A long-term disorder causing extreme tiredness not relieved by rest. Exact cause remains unknown.
Hardening and narrowing of arteries due to cholesterol plaque buildup. It reduces oxygen flow to heart and brain.
Blockage of coronary arteries causing decreased blood supply to heart. Major risk factor for heart attack.
Also known as heart attack — caused by sudden artery blockage. Immediate medical attention is life-saving.
Heart's pumping ability weakens leading to fluid buildup in lungs or legs. Often follows hypertension or heart attack.
Heart muscle becomes weak or enlarged reducing pumping efficiency. It can be genetic or stress-induced.
Bacterial infection of heart valves causing inflammation. Untreated cases lead to heart failure or embolism.
Inflammation of the membrane around the heart. Pain worsens when lying flat and eases while sitting forward.
Irregular heartbeat that may cause lightheadedness or fainting. Some forms can be fatal if untreated.
Bulging of the aorta due to wall weakness. If ruptured, it causes massive internal bleeding.
Precautions: Regular scan;Blood pressure control;Avoid heavy lifting

Description: Narrowing of arteries in limbs causing pain while walking. Common in smokers and diabetics.
Blood clot formation in deep veins, usually in legs. Can cause pulmonary embolism if dislodged.
Enlarged twisted veins caused by poor valve function. More common in standing jobs and pregnancy.
Blood clot travels to lungs blocking blood flow. A life-threatening emergency requiring immediate care.
Chronic inflammation of airways causing reversible breathing difficulty. Triggers include dust and cold air.
A progressive lung disease mostly caused by smoking. Includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
Inflammation of bronchial tubes leading to mucus buildup. Caused by infection or smoking.
Infection causing fluid accumulation in lungs. Can be viral, bacterial, or fungal.
Contagious lung infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Requires long-term antibiotic treatment.
Malignant tumor in lung tissue mostly caused by smoking. Detected by imaging and biopsy.
Scarring of lung tissue making breathing difficult. Can result from toxins or autoimmune disorders.
Destruction of lung alveoli due to smoking or pollutants. Causes chronic oxygen deficiency.
Permanent widening of bronchi leading to frequent infections. Causes persistent cough with mucus.
Breathing pauses during sleep reducing oxygen levels. Often linked to obesity or airway obstruction.
Inflammatory disease forming granulomas in lungs or skin. Severity varies by organ involvement.
Fluid buildup between lung layers compressing the lungs. Usually secondary to infection or cancer.
Collapsed lung due to air leakage into pleural space. Can occur spontaneously or from trauma.
Hard mineral deposits forming in kidneys or urinary tract. Causes severe pain when passing through ureter.
Gradual loss of kidney function leading to toxin buildup. Often caused by diabetes or hypertension.
Sudden kidney failure due to dehydration, infection, or drugs. Potentially reversible if treated early.
Inflammation of kidney filters caused by infection or autoimmune disease. Leads to fluid retention and high BP.
Kidney disorder causing protein loss in urine. Common in children and diabetics.
Inherited disorder where fluid-filled cysts form in kidneys. Causes progressive kidney failure.
Bacterial infection in urinary tract, common in females. Causes burning and lower abdominal pain.
Chronic bladder inflammation without infection. Causes persistent pelvic pain and urinary frequency.
Inflammation of prostate gland causing pain and discomfort. May be bacterial or chronic non-bacterial.
End-stage loss of kidney function leading to toxin accumulation. Requires dialysis or transplant.
Swelling of kidneys due to urine backup. Usually caused by stones or obstruction.
Bacterial infection of kidneys spreading from bladder. Can cause sepsis if untreated.
Inflammation of blood vessels affecting multiple organs. Leads to poor circulation and tissue damage.
Abnormal narrowing of small blood vessels in fingers due to cold. Common in autoimmune disorders.
Inflammation of veins with clot formation. Common in varicose veins or prolonged immobility.
Fluid buildup due to lymphatic obstruction. Can follow cancer surgery or infection.
Life-threatening bloodstream infection spreading from other organs. Requires urgent antibiotics.
Sudden drop in blood flow due to trauma, infection, or allergy. Leads to organ failure if untreated.
A progressive neurodegenerative disease that destroys motor neurons. Causes loss of muscle control and breathing difficulty.
An autoimmune disorder where immune cells attack peripheral nerves. Can progress rapidly but often recoverable.
An autoimmune disease impairing nerve-muscle communication. Symptoms worsen with activity and improve with rest.
Nerve damage causing burning or loss of sensation in hands and feet. Common in diabetes and alcohol abuse.
Sudden paralysis of one side of the face due to facial-nerve inflammation. Usually temporary and recovers within weeks.
Brain damage before or at birth affecting movement and posture. Non-progressive but lifelong.
A rare neurodegenerative disorder combining Parkinson-like and autonomic symptoms.
Genetic disorders causing progressive muscle loss. Often leads to wheelchair dependency.
Degeneration of joint cartilage leading to pain and reduced mobility. Common in knees and hips.
Autoimmune inflammation of joints causing deformity if untreated. Affects multiple joints symmetrically.
Inflammatory arthritis affecting spine and sacroiliac joints. Causes stooped posture over time.
Wear-and-tear of cervical spine causing nerve compression and pain.
Abnormal sideways curvature of spine seen in adolescence. Severe cases affect breathing.
Excessive forward curvature of upper spine. Caused by poor posture or osteoporosis.
Inward curvature of lower spine due to muscle imbalance. Improves with stretching and strengthening.
Weak bones due to mineral loss increasing fracture risk. Common in older women.
Abnormal bone remodeling leading to enlarged and weak bones. Affects pelvis, spine, and skull.
Chronic pain disorder causing tenderness and exhaustion. Often linked to stress and poor sleep.
Adrenal insufficiency reducing cortisol and aldosterone. Leads to dehydration and salt craving.
Excess cortisol from steroids or tumor. Causes fragile skin and mood swings.
Overactive parathyroid raising calcium levels. Leads to kidney stones and bone fragility.
Low parathyroid hormone causing calcium deficiency and muscle spasms.
A rare adrenal tumor producing excess adrenaline. Causes spikes in blood pressure.
Abnormal growth in pituitary gland affecting hormone levels. May cause infertility or acromegaly.
Excess growth hormone in adults causing bone thickening and organ enlargement.
Hormone disorder reducing kidney’s water retention ability. Leads to extreme thirst and diluted urine.
Hormonal imbalance causing cysts on ovaries and insulin resistance. Affects fertility and mood.
Natural decline of female hormones ending menstrual cycle. Can cause mood and sleep changes.
Physical and emotional symptoms before menstruation. Related to hormonal fluctuations.
High prolactin levels due to pituitary dysfunction. Can cause infertility and visual disturbances.
Persistent spinal pain due to injury or poor posture. Common occupational issue.
Nerve compression in cervical spine radiating pain to arm and shoulder.
Pain along the sciatic nerve due to herniated disc or compression. Worsens with prolonged sitting.
Median nerve compression at wrist causing hand pain and weakness. Common in computer users.
Inflammation of tendons due to overuse or strain. Common in shoulders and wrists.
Inflammation of fluid sacs cushioning joints. Causes pain during movement.
Inflammation of plantar tissue under foot causing sharp heel pain. Common in runners.
Inflammation and thickening of shoulder capsule limiting motion. Often post-injury or diabetes-related.
Tendon strain from repetitive motion affecting elbow. Pain worsens during grip.
Widespread pain disorder involving muscles and soft tissues. Often overlaps with anxiety or depression.
Nerve dysfunction causing severe pain after injury or surgery. Pain is disproportionate to trauma.
Jaw joint inflammation leading to chewing difficulty and ear pain.
An allergic reaction to dust or pollen causing nasal inflammation. Symptoms peak during seasonal changes.
Chronic airway inflammation triggered by allergens or cold. Causes breathing difficulty and wheezing.
Chronic inflammatory skin condition with itching and dryness. Often worsened by stress or irritants.
Autoimmune skin disorder causing scaly plaques. Common on elbows and scalp.
Inflammatory skin reaction to irritants or allergens. Heals with avoidance and topical care.
Immune overreaction to medication causing hives or anaphylaxis. Requires urgent medical attention.
Immune system reaction to certain foods like nuts or seafood. Can lead to anaphylaxis if untreated.
Severe systemic allergic reaction causing airway closure. Immediate treatment with adrenaline is vital.
Autoimmune disease attacking multiple organs and skin. Flares worsen with stress or sunlight.
Autoimmune inflammation damaging joint linings. Causes deformity and disability if untreated.
Autoimmune disorder reducing tear and saliva production. Causes chronic dryness and discomfort.
Autoimmune reaction to gluten damaging small intestine. Causes nutrient malabsorption.
Autoimmune thyroid disease causing underactive metabolism. Common in women.
Autoimmune hyperthyroidism causing increased metabolism. Often with eye bulging or tremors.
Cancer of blood-forming tissues producing abnormal white cells. Weakens immunity and causes anemia.
Cancer of lymphatic system causing swelling and fever. Treated with chemo or radiation.
Cancer of plasma cells in bone marrow. Causes brittle bones and kidney issues.
Deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin causing fatigue. Often linked to poor nutrition or chronic disease.
Inherited red blood cell disorder causing blockages and pain crises. Common in tropical regions.
Genetic anemia requiring frequent transfusions. Leads to iron overload and fatigue.
Inherited bleeding disorder due to clotting factor deficiency. Even small cuts cause prolonged bleeding.
Overproduction of red blood cells thickening blood. Increases risk of stroke or clots.
Low platelet count causing easy bleeding and bruising. May follow viral infections or drugs.
Pre-leukemic condition causing abnormal bone marrow cell production. Progresses to anemia and weakness.
Type of blood cancer with abnormal lymphocyte growth. High cure rate with early therapy.
Group of lymphatic cancers with variable progression. Detected by biopsy and imaging.
Parasitic infection spread by mosquitoes. Causes cyclic fever and anemia.
Mosquito-borne viral fever causing pain and platelet loss. Severe cases lead to dengue hemorrhagic fever.
Viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes causing severe joint pain. Symptoms can last for weeks.
Mosquito-transmitted virus often mild but dangerous in pregnancy. Can cause fetal abnormalities.
Viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes causing liver damage and bleeding. Vaccine-preventable.
Bacterial infection from contaminated water or soil. Affects liver and kidneys.
Bacterial infection spread by contaminated food and water. Causes prolonged high fever.
Bacterial infection causing rapid dehydration. Spread through contaminated water.
Bacterial infection transmitted by fleas or rodents. Historically caused pandemics.
Parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes causing limb swelling. Common in tropical areas.
Parasitic disease spread by sandflies affecting liver and spleen. Fatal if untreated.
Also known as sleeping sickness — transmitted by tsetse flies. Affects nervous system and causes coma.
Parasitic worms infecting blood vessels via freshwater. Causes liver and urinary damage.
River blindness caused by parasitic worms spread by flies. Causes skin and eye lesions.
Severe viral hemorrhagic fever with high fatality. Spread through body fluids or contact.
Deadly viral infection similar to Ebola. Causes severe hemorrhage and organ failure.
Fatal viral disease transmitted by animal bites. Affects nervous system causing aggression and paralysis.
Bacterial toxin infection causing muscle contractions. Spread through wounds or rust exposure.
Bacterial infection from animal products or inhalation. Can be fatal if untreated.
Bacterial infection from unpasteurized dairy or animals. Causes chronic fever and muscle pain.
Viral disease from rodent droppings causing lung failure. High mortality if untreated.
Deadly zoonotic virus affecting brain and lungs. Transmitted from bats or pigs.
